keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum has faced multiple security breaches, including a recent jewelry heist in October 2025, where thieves broke into the Apollo Gallery and stole high-value items.
The crown of Empress Eugénie, a 1354-diamond, 56-emerald piece, was damaged during the heist and was found outside the museum.
The Louvre has a long history of security issues, including the 1911 theft of the 'Mona Lisa' and the 1983 theft of 16th-century armor, which was returned in 2021.
Overcrowding, structural damage, and poor visitor services have been longstanding issues, with a 2025 internal memo warning of deteriorating conditions and insufficient public services.
French President Emmanuel Macron announced plans to move the 'Mona Lisa' to a dedicated room as part of a 10-year renovation project to improve access, safety, and visitor experience.
The museum’s popularity, with over 8.7 million visitors in 2024, has strained its infrastructure, leading to water leaks, temperature fluctuations, and staff shortages.
In June 2025, the museum temporarily closed due to staff strikes over overcrowding and poor working conditions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Louvre Museum in Paris suffered a high-profile jewelry heist on October 19, 2025, where thieves broke into the Apollo Gallery and stole high-value items, including damaging the crown of Empress Eugénie. This incident, occurring just days after staff strikes and internal warnings about overcrowding and structural decay, underscores a long-standing pattern of security and operational challenges. The museum has a history of thefts, including the 1911 'Mona Lisa' heist by Vincenzo Peruggia and the 1983 theft of Renaissance armor, later returned in 2021. Internal reports from 2025 reveal deteriorating infrastructure, including water leaks, temperature fluctuations, and insufficient visitor services. French President Emmanuel Macron has pledged to create a dedicated room for the 'Mona Lisa' as part of a 10-year renovation plan to improve safety and accessibility. The heist has triggered public and political scrutiny, highlighting the immense pressure on one of the world’s most visited cultural landmarks.
title: Jewelry Heist at the Louvre is Latest Problem to Beset France’s Most Famous Museum
